7.1.38{{cite web | url = https://fah-web.stanford.edu/projects/FAHClient/wiki/BetaRelease | title = Folding@Home v7 Client Beta Release Page | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-19 }} | latest preview date = {{Start date and age|2011|10|10}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=67&t=19795 | title = FAHClient V7.1.38 released (4th Open-Beta) | author = Joseph Coffland | date = 2011-10-10 | accessdate = 2011-10-10}} | operating system = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Linux]] | platform = [[Cross-platform]] | language = English | genre = [[Distributed computing]] | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]]{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/License | title = Folding@home Distributed Computing Client | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2010-08-26 }} | website = {{URL|folding.stanford.edu}} }} '''Folding@home''' is a [[distributed computing]] project designed to use spare processing power on personal computers to perform simulations of disease-relevant [[protein folding]] and other [[molecular dynamics]], and to improve on the methods of doing so. Also referred to as '''FAH''' or '''F@h''', much of its work attempts to determine how proteins reach their [[Protein tertiary structure|final structure]], which is of significant academic interest and has implications to both [[Medical research|disease research]] and [[nanotechnology]]. To a lesser degree Folding@home also tries to [[Protein structure prediction|predict]] that final structure from only the initial [[amino acid]] sequence, which has applications in [[drug design]].{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=17&t=14179#p139017 | title = Re: FAH really doing anything? | author = Imran "ihaque" Haque (Pande lab member) | date = 2010-08-11 | accessdate = 2011-08-23}} Folding@home is developed and operated by the Pande Laboratory at [[Stanford University]], under the direction of [[Vijay Pande]].{{cite web | url = http://www.stanford.edu/group/pandegroup/folding/FoldingFAQ.pdf | title = Folding@Home Executive summary | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-10-04}} The goal of the project is to "understand protein folding, misfolding, and related diseases".{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu | title = Folding@home - Main | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-10-04}} Folding@home's simulations of protein folding and misfolding enable the scientific community to better understand the development of many diseases, including [[Alzheimer's disease]], [[Parkinson's disease]], [[cancer]], [[CreutzfeldtâJakob disease]], [[Huntington's disease]], [[cystic fibrosis]], [[sickle-cell anaemia]], [[HIV]], [[Chagas disease]], [[influenza]], [[osteogenesis imperfecta]], [[autism]],{{cite journal | author = Antonella De Jaco, Michael Z. Lin, Noga Dubi, Davide Comoletti, Meghan T. Miller, Shelley Camp, Mark Ellisman, Margaret T. Butko, Roger Y. Tsien, and Palmer Taylor | title = Neuroligin Trafficking Deficiencies Arising from Mutations in the a/Ã-Hydrolase Fold Protein Family | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | year = 2010 | volume = 285 | issue = 37 | pages = 28674â28682 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M110.139519 | pmid = 20615874 | pmc = 2937894}} and [[alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency]], among others.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/FAQ-diseases.html | title = Folding@home Diseases Studied FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | accessdate = 2011-09-23}} More fundamentally, understanding the process of protein folding â how proteins assemble themselves into a functional state â is one of the outstanding problems of [[molecular biology]].{{cite web | url = http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Publications/Papers/PDF/HU96/HU96.pdf | title = Knowledge Based Structure Prediction of the Light-Harvesting Complex II of Rhodospirillum molischianum | author = Xiche Hu, Dong Xu, Kenneth Hamer, Klaus Schulten, Juergen Koepke, and Hartmut Michel | year = 1991 | accessdate = 2011-09-10}} The Pande lab has produced ninety-five [[Academic publishing|scientific research papers]] as a direct result of the project,{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/Papers | title = Folding@home - Papers | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | date = 2011-08-05 | accessdate = 2011-10-09}} and Folding@home has caused paradigm shifts in protein folding theory.{{cite journal | author = V. S. Pande, K. Beauchamp, and G. R. Bowman | title = Everything you wanted to know about Markov State Models but were afraid to ask | journal = Methods | year = 2010 | volume = 52 | issue = 1 | pages = 99â105 | doi = 10.1016/j.ymeth.2010.06.002 | pmc = 2933958 | pmid = 20570730}} In January 2010 the Folding@home project successfully simulated protein folding in the 1.5 [[millisecond]] range â a simulation thousands of times longer than ever previously achieved.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2010/01/major-new-result-from-foldinghome-simulation-of-the-millisecond-timescale.html | title = Folding@home: Paper #72: Major new result for Folding@home: Simulation of the millisecond timescale | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2010-01-17 | accessdate = 2011-09-08}} Folding@home has pioneered the uses of [[GPU]]s, [[multi-core processor]]s, and [[PlayStation 3]]s for distributed computing. It remains one of the world's fastest computing systems, and is more powerful than all distributed computing projects under [[BOINC]] combined. Folding@home's distributed simulations remain accurate compared to results from laboratory research, a "grand challenge" in [[computational biology]].{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-Press | title = Folding@Home Press FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | accessdate = 2011-08-31}} The Pande lab's goal is to refine Folding@home's methods to the level where it will become an essential tool for molecular medical research, and they collaborate with various scientific institutions and laboratories across the world.{{cite web | url = http://castroller.com/Podcasts/FuturesInBiotech/249153 | title = Futures in Biotech 27: Folding@home at 1.3 Petaflops | format = Interview, webcast | date = 2007-12-28}}{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/About | title = Folding@home - About | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-08-31}} ==Biomedical significance== {{further | [[Protein folding]]}} [[Image:Protein folding.png|thumb | right | 300px | Illustration of a protein before and after folding]] [[Protein]]s are an essential component to many biological functions, and participate in virtually every process within cells. They often act as [[enzymes]], performing biochemical reactions including [[cell signaling]], transportation, [[Cell cycle#Regulation of eukaryotic cell cycle|cellular regulation]], and others. As structural elements, some proteins act as a type of [[cytoskeleton | skeleton for cells]], and as [[antibodies]] other proteins help the [[immune system]].{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/Science | title = The Science Behind Folding@home | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | year = 2009 | accessdate = 2011-08-15}} Before a protein can take on these roles, it must fold into a functional [[Protein tertiary structure | three-dimensional shape]] based on a particular series of [[Reaction intermediate|steps]], which often occur [[Spontaneous process | spontaneously]].{{cite journal | author = Anfinsen, C.B., Haber, E., Sela, M., White Jr., F.H. | title = The kinetics of formation of native ribonuclease during oxidation of the reduced polypeptide chain | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | year = 1961 | volume = 45 | issue = 1 | pages = 1309â1314 | doi = | issn = 00278424 | pmc = | pmid = }}{{cite book | last = Alberts | first = Bruce | coauthors = Alexander Johnson, Julian Lewis, Martin Raff, Keith Roberts, and Peter Walters | title = Molecular Biology of the Cell; Fourth Edition | publisher = Garland Science | year = 2002 | location = New York and London | chapter = The Shape and Structure of Proteins | isbn = 0-8153-3218-1 | authorlink = Bruce Alberts}} Understanding protein folding is thus critical to understanding what a protein does and how it works. Moreover, when proteins do not fold correctlyâthat is, when they fold down the wrong pathway and end up misshapenâthey can [[Protein aggregation|aggregate]] and cause serious and in some cases life-threatening diseases.{{cite journal | author = Uversky, V.N. | title = Intrinsic disorder in proteins associated with neurodegenerative diseases | journal = Frontiers in Bioscience | year = 2009 | volume = 14 | issue = 14 | pages = 5188â5238 | doi = 10.2741/3594 | issn = 10939946 | pmc = | pmid = }}{{cite web | url = http://www.proteinfoldingcenter.org/ | title = Center for Protein Folding Machinery | publisher = Protein Folding Center | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-09-30}} However, once the misfolding process is determined, figuring out its prevention can be the next step, and preventative treatments can be applied during the folding process. While the understanding of protein folding requires a combination of theories and experiments, creating experimentally comparable simulations of protein folding dynamics remains difficult and is considered a "holy grail" of [[computational biology]].{{cite web | url = http://biox.stanford.edu/clark/pande.html | title = Bio-X Stanford University: Vijay Pande | publisher = Bio-X Stanford University | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-10-16}} Folding@home's distributed computing methods can address these challenges and allow for unique insights into the complexity of protein folding while strongly agreeing with experimental data.{{cite journal | author = G. Bowman, V. Volez, and V. S. Pande | title = Taming the complexity of protein folding | journal = Current Opinion in Structural Biology | year = 2011 | volume = 21 | issue = 1 | pages = 4â11 | doi = 10.1016/j.sbi.2010.10.006 | pmc = 3042729 | pmid = 21081274}}{{cite journal | author = Vijay S. Pande, Ian Baker, Jarrod Chapman, Sidney P. Elmer, Siraj Khaliq, Stefan M. Larson, Young Min Rhee, Michael R. Shirts, Christopher D. Snow, Eric J. Sorin, Bojan Zagrovic | title = Atomistic protein folding simulations on the submillisecond timescale using worldwide distributed computing | journal = Biopolymers | year = 2002 | volume = 68 | issue = 1 | pages = 91â109 | doi = 10.1002/bip.10219 | pmid = 12579582}} Since the late 1990s, simulations of protein molecular dynamics have been severely limited by computational power. Straightforward approaches have exceptional difficulty for all but the most elementary of systems, which has prompted the use of simplified [[Native state | native]]-centric ''[[in silico]]'' molecular models.{{cite journal | author = C. D. Snow, E. J. Sorin, Y. M. Rhee, and V. S. Pande. | title = How well can simulation predict protein folding kinetics and thermodynamics? | journal = Annual Reviews of Biophysics | year = 2005 | volume = 34 | issue = | pages = 43â69 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.biophys.34.040204.144447 | pmid = 15869383}} Not only are these models insufficient for a comprehensive view of protein folding, but the traditional methods of using a small number of very long simulations cannot accurately capture enough detailed information into how a protein misfolds.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?p=188496#p188392 | title = Re: Course grained Protein folding in under 10 minutes | author = TJ Lane (Pande lab member) | date = 2011-06-09 | accessdate = 2011-10-29}} Moreover, these simplified models often ignore how [[solvent]]s such as water might affect the folding process. In strong agreement with experimental observations, its influence was revealed in 2004 using Folding@home's computational power and explicit solvation simulations.{{cite journal | author = Young Min Rhee, Eric J. Sorin, Guha Jayachandran, Erik Lindahl, & Vijay S Pande | title = Simulations of the role of water in the protein-folding mechanism | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, USA | year = 2004 | volume = 101 | issue = 17 | pages = 6456â6461 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0307898101 | pmid = 15090647 | pmc = 404066|bibcode = 2004PNAS..101.6456R}} This observation was made possible by Folding@home's statistical assembly of many shorter simulations, which compared to traditional approaches, provide a much more complete description of the protein's [[energy landscape]], [[configuration space|conformation space]], and [[equilibrium thermodynamics]].{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/01/random-thoughts.html | title = Random thoughts on the superbowl and statistics | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-01-23 | accessdate = 2011-09-11}} While some of these simulations may work themselves into impossible atomic configurations or into the correct native state, others will illustrate how that protein misfolds. By utilizing [[thermodynamics]], Folding@home uses methods that can find these rare events without having to complete many simulations.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2007/09/what-can-thermo.html | title = What can Thermodynamics tell us? | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2007-09-29 | accessdate = 2011-10-29}}{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2007/09/how-fah-works-t.html | title = How FAH works: Thermodynamic alchemy | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2007-09-30 | accessdate = 2011-10-29}} This allows for a highly accurate and thorough exploration of protein configurations in a reasonable amount of time, even over very long simulation timescales.{{cite journal | author = Stefan M. Larson, Christopher D. Snow, Michael R. Shirts, and Vijay S. Pande | title = Folding@home and Genome@home: Using distributed computing to tackle previously intractable problems in computational biology | journal = Computational Genomics | year = 2002 | volume = | issue = | pages = | doi = | pmid = | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/papers/Horizon_Review.pdf}} For the instrumental development of the software behind these statistical approaches and for attaining quantitative agreement between theory and experiment, in 2010 Folding@home researcher Greg Bowman was awarded the [[Thomas Kuhn]] Paradigm Shift Award from the [[American Chemical Society]].{{cite web | url = https://simtk.org/project/xml/news.xml?group_id=357 | title = Greg Bowman awarded the 2010 Kuhn Paradigm Shift Award | publisher = SimTK: MSMBuilder | date = 2010-03-29 | accessdate = 2011-11-30}}{{cite web | url = http://web2011.acscomp.org/awards/thomas-kuhn-paradigm-shift-award | title = Thomas Kuhn Paradigm Shift Award | publisher = ACS: Computers in Chemistry | accessdate = 2011-11-30}} The Pande lab and other researchers can use Folding@home to study aspects of folding, misfolding, and related diseases that would never be seen experimentally. For example, most proteins have such intrinsically stable [[native state]]s that it is difficult to experimentally study their folding events, and researchers must resort to chemical [[Denaturation (biochemistry) | denaturation]] methods.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=3430 | title = Project 3430 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-11-30}} While the denatured state of proteins is of scientific interest because any residual structure may affect its folding behavior, even with molecular experiments it remains difficult to determine the extent of a local structure that may be present. However, molecular simulations on Folding@home can provide detail into denatured conformational states and insights into the chemical denaturation mechanisms. These and other simulations run on Folding@home are used in conjunction with laboratory experiments. Additionally, as of 2011 the Pande lab is performing studies into how protein folding in their native [[Cell (biology)|cells]] may be different than in environments such as [[test tube]]s used during experiments.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=19376&start=0#p193378 | title = Projects 7808 and 7809 to full fah | author = Christian "schwancr" Schwantes (Pande lab member) | date = 2011-08-15 | accessdate = 2011-10-16}}{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2007/11/paper-highlig-1.html | title = Paper highlight: paper #50 & #36 | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2007-11-16 | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} In addition to the diseases listed below, researchers use Folding@home to study [[malaria]], [[Chagas disease]], the [[amylin]] peptide involved in [[type II diabetes]],{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=2974 | title = Project 2974 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} and the [[prion]]s which cause [[CreutzfeldtâJakob disease]].{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=6811 | title = Project 6811 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} Results from this research have led to major shifts in the understanding of protein folding and its applications for disease, as well as improved protein folding models.{{cite journal | author = G. R. Bowman and V. S. Pande | title = Protein folded states are kinetic hubs | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, USA | year = 2010 | volume = 107 | issue = 24 | pages = 10890â10895 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1003962107 | pmc = 2890711 | pmid=20534497 | bibcode = 2010PNAS..10710890B}}{{cite journal | author = V. S. Pande | title = A simple theory of protein folding kinetics | journal = Physical Review Letters | year = 2010 | volume = 105 | issue = 19 | pages = | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.105.198101 | pmc = | pmid = | bibcode = 2010PhRvL.105s8101P}} Folding@home is dedicated to producing significant amounts of results towards protein folding, the diseases that result from protein misfolding, and novel computational methods for doing so. The goal of the first five years of the project was to make significant advances in understanding folding, while the current goal is to understand misfolding and related disease, especially Alzheimer's disease.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2011/08/results-page-updated-new-key-result-published-in-our-work-in-alzheimers-disease.html | title = Results page updated â new key result published in our work in Alzheimer's Disease | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2011-08-05 | accessdate = 2011-09-10}} As a part of Stanford University, a non-profit organization, the Pande lab does not sell the results generated by Folding@home. The large data sets from the project are freely available for other researchers to use upon request, and some can be accessed from the Folding@home website.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/04/foldinghome-and.html | title = Folding@home and Simbios | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-04-23 | accessdate = 2011-11-09}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=19643&p=197898#p197898 | title = Re: Suggested Changes to F@h Website | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2011-10-25 | accessdate = 2011-10-25}} The Pande lab also releases Folding@home's key software to other researchers, so that the algorithms which benefit Folding@home will also aid other scientific areas. Moreover, in 2011 they released the [[open-source]] Copernicus software, so that other researchers can run molecular simulations much more efficiently on [[Computer cluster | clusters]] or supercomputers.{{cite web | url = http://news.stanford.edu/news/2011/november/modeling-protein-folding-111811.html | title = New Stanford software takes Folding@home's biological research to supercomputers | author = Sarah Jane Keller | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | date = 2011-11-18 | accessdate = 2011-11-30}} Summaries of all of the scientific findings from Folding@home are posted on the Folding@home website after publication. The full publications are available online or from a local municipal or academic library. ===Alzheimer's disease=== [[File:Amyloid-plaque formation-big.jpg | 550px | thumb | Enzymes act on the [[amyloid precursor protein]] and cut it into AÃ fragments, which then aggregate to form [[senile plaques]]; characteristic of Alzheimer's patients.]] [[Alzheimer's disease]], a form of [[dementia]] which most often affects the elderly, is believed to be caused by specific misfolding and subsequent [[Protein aggregation|aggregation]] of the small 42-[[amino acid|residue]] [[amyloid beta]] (AÃ) [[peptide]]. The severity of the disease depends not only on the amount of AÃ, but also on how it misfolds. Current theory holds that toxic non-[[senile plaques|plaque]] AÃ [[oligomers]] (aggregates of many [[monomers]]) bind to a [[cell surface receptor|surface receptor]] on [[neuron]]s and change the structure of the [[synapse]], thereby disrupting neuronal communication and causing neuronal [[cell death]] which leads to the associated [[neurodegenerative]] consequences.{{cite journal | author = Lacor PN,''et al.'' | title = AÃ Oligomer-Induced Aberrations in Synapse Composition, Shape, and Density Provide a Molecular Basis for Loss of Connectivity in Alzheimer's Disease | journal = Journal of Neuroscience | volume = 27 | issue = 4 | pages = 796â807 | year = 2007 | month = January | pmid = 17251419 | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.3501-06.2007 | last2 = Buniel | first2 = MC | last3 = Furlow | first3 = PW | last4 = Clemente | first4 = AS | last5 = Velasco | first5 = PT | last6 = Wood | first6 = M | last7 = Viola | first7 = KL | last8 = Klein | first8 = WL}}{{cite journal | author = P. Novick, J. Rajadas, C.W. Liu, N. W. Kelley, M. Inayathullah, and V. S. Pande | title = Rationally Designed Turn Promoting Mutation in the Amyloid-Ã Peptide Sequence Stabilizes Oligomers in Solution | journal = PLoS ONE | year = 2011 | volume = 6 | issue = 7 | pages = e21776 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0021776 | pmc = 3142112 | pmid = 21799748 | editor1-last = Buehler | editor1-first = Markus J.}} Understanding how and why this peptide misfolds could result in key insights into how to cure Alzheimer's Disease, and will also help the Pande lab prepare for similar aggregation studies.{{cite journal | author = Nicholas W. Kelley, V. Vishal, Grant A. Krafft, and Vijay S. Pande. | title = Simulating oligomerization at experimental concentrations and long timescales: A Markov state model approach | journal = Journal of Chemical Physics | year = 2008 | volume = 129 | issue = 21 | pages = 214707 | doi = 10.1063/1.3010881 | pmid = 19063575 | pmc = 2674793 | bibcode = 2008JChPh.129u4707K}} Despite this connection, toxic AÃ aggregations remain so complex that it was not previously possible to simulate them in atomic resolution. In 2011, the Pande lab explored how their Abeta studies using Folding@home could be used as a starting point for a new Alzheimer's therapy. Folding@home is currently concentrating on Alzheimer's and continues full-scale simulations of amyloid beta and its oligomerization,{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=6802 | title = Project 6802 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} which had previously been a technological challenge to simulate. These studies build off of the Pande lab's 2008 published work into new ways to simulate Abeta [[oligomerization]] over long timescales. In the same publication, previous all-atom simulations were performed that led to specific experimentally-tested predictions, such as ways in which to stabilize the protein and prevent the toxic oligomer formation. The Pande lab is focusing their research in this area for rational [[drug design]] approaches. Pande described that paper as the "tip of the iceberg" for the Folding@home studies of Alzheimer's, as further results will follow and possibly new therapeutics. Folding@home is also being used to study AÃ fragments of different sizes to determine how various natural enzymes affect the structure and folding of AÃ. These fragments are tied to senile plaques, a pathological marker of Alzheimer's disease in patient's brain. When certain enzymes cleave the [[amyloid precursor protein]], Abeta peptides are produced, while the action of other enzymes can instead produce p3 peptides, much smaller fragments of AÃ. Folding@home is simulating one of these smaller peptides in water in an effort to determine how the length of AÃ affects its overall structure.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=6871 | title = Project 6871 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} In 2010, several possible drug leads predicted by Folding@home went from the [[test tube]] to testing on living [[Tissue (biology)|tissue]], and in close cooperation with the Nanomedicine Center for Protein Folding, the drug leads continued to be refined. Additionally, as predicted by FAH's simulations, a stable form of amyloid beta was experimentally verified which the Pande lab believes could be used as a starting point for new Alzheimer's therapy. In 2008, Folding@home produced several small drug candidates to fight Alzheimer's Disease, as they appear to inhibit the toxicity of Abeta.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/12/new-fah-results-on-possible-new-alzheimers-drug-presented.html | title = New FAH results on possible new Alzheimer's drug presented | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-12-18 | accessdate = 2011-09-23}} The Pande lab is also using Folding@home to investigate [[proteinâprotein interaction]]s, which occur extensively throughout both benign and disease-related biological activities. Interactions involving the common [[SH3 domain|SH3]] protein are also being studied, as it has implications in Alzheimers research. The refinement of these simulations has greatly improved the Pande lab's ability to understand a wide variety of biological interactions.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=700 | title = Project 700 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} ===Huntington's disease=== [[Huntington's disease]], an incurable [[neurodegenerative]] genetic disorder affecting [[Motor coordination|muscle coordination]] and leading to [[dementia]], is also associated with protein misfolding. Specifically, it is caused by a mutation in the [[Huntingtin gene]], which causes excessively long [[polyglutamine tract|repetitive chains]] of the [[glutamine]] amino acid in the [[Huntingtin protein]], a protein that plays important roles in [[nerve cells]].{{cite journal | author = Walker FO | title = Huntington's disease | journal = Lancet | volume = 369 | issue = 9557 | page = 220 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17240289 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(07)60111-1}}{{cite journal | author = Nicholas W. Kelley, Xuhui Huang, Stephen Tam, Christoph Spiess, Judith Frydman and Vijay S. Pande | title = The predicted structure of the headpiece of the Huntingtin protein and its implications on Huntingtin aggregation | journal = Journal of Molecular Biology | year = 2009 | volume = 388 | issue = 5 | pages = 919â27 | doi = 10.1016/j.jmb.2009.01.032 | pmid = 19361448 | pmc = 2677131}} The likelihood of neuronal cell death is primarily affected by the length of the glutamine chain and the neuron's intracellular exposure to the misfolded Huntingtin protein.{{cite journal | author = Orr HT | title = Neurodegenerative disease: neuron protection agency | journal = Nature | volume = 431 | issue = 7010 | pages = 747â8 | year = 2004 | month = October | pmid = 15483586 | doi = 10.1038/431747a | url = }} The defective protein causes Huntington's by aggregating most often in the [[striatum]] and [[frontal cortex]] of patient's brains. The Pande lab is using Folding@home to study these aggregates, as well as predict how they form. How this aggregation occurs has been largely unknown, but in 2009 a paper based off of Folding@home's results and published in the [[Journal of Molecular Biology]] investigated possible mechanisms for the aggregation formation, and the implications into how to prevent it. These studies will be useful for [[drug design]] approaches against the disease, and will serve as a foundation for methods to stop the aggregation formation. Additionally, some of the methods used to study Huntington's are also being used for Alzheimer's research. In 2010, Folding@home researcher Veena Thomas proposed a novel therapeutic strategy for HD, which may be funded by the [[National Institutes of Health|NIH]]. This strategy could be used to bring the results from Folding@home directly to a therapeutic. ===Cancer=== More than half of all known [[cancer]]s involve mutations in [[p53]], a tumor suppressor protein present in every cell which signals for cell death in the event of damage to a cell's [[DNA]]. If p53 becomes mutated, breaks down, or fails to fold properly, it will no longer be able to cause the "stop signal" for cell division. Cells will consequently divide and grow uncontrollably to form tumors.{{cite journal | author = L.T. Chong, W. C. Swope, J. W. Pitera, and V. S. Pande | title = A novel approach for computational alanine scanning: application to the p53 oligomerization domain | journal = Journal of Molecular Biology | year = 2006 | volume = 357 | issue = 3 | pages = 1039â1049 | doi = 10.1016/j.jmb.2005.12.083 | pmid = 16457841}} Folding@home is used to study specific properties of p53 in order to understand and predict these mutations, and in 2007 work began to develop inhibitor proteins that deactivate damaged p53. The Pande lab has also developed a novel experimentally-verified method for predicting how mutations affect p53, which has had reasonable success in the identification of deleterious mutations such as those linked to cancer. This supplemented work performed in 2005 that studied how mutations affect the folding of p53, and which mutations are relevant to cancer. While it was the first peer-reviewed publication from a distributed computing project related to cancer,{{cite web | url = http://web.archive.org/web/20070706192334/http://forum.folding-community.org/viewtopic.php?t=10950 | title = First results from Folding@Home cancer project published | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2005-01-16 | accessdate = 2011-11-09}} the study also agreed well with experiments and offered insights that were previously unobtainable.{{cite journal | author = L. T. Chong, C. D. Snow, Y. M. Rhee, and V. S. Pande. | title = Dimerization of the p53 Oligomerization Domain: Identification of a Folding Nucleus by Molecular Dynamics Simulations | journal = Journal of Molecular Biology | year = 2004 | volume = 345 | issue = 4 | pages = 869â878 | doi = 10.1016/j.jmb.2004.10.083 | pmid = 15588832}} Following these results, the Pande lab have expanded their work to other p53-related diseases. The Pande lab is also performing research into [[Chaperone (protein) | protein chaperones]]. These are proteins that assist in the folding of other molecules, assembly of oligomeric structures, the prevention of potential damage caused by protein misfolding, and other functions. They are needed for these purposes by rapidly growing cancerous cells.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2007/09/nanomedicine-ce.html | title = Nanomedicine center | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2007-09-28 | accessdate = 2011-09-23}} Using Folding@home and working closely with the Protein Folding Center, they plan to find ways to inhibit chaperones involved in cancer. Using Folding@home for a more comprehensive visualization of their functions, the Pande lab and the Protein Folding Center collectively plan to engineer modified chaperonins to inhibit the folding of particular proteins associated with human diseases such as cancer and Alzheimer's. While this approach has been used before, they believe that this project, if successful, could lead to an interesting new drug against cancer or at least make major advances in that area. Folding@home is also used to study the folding of several other proteins which have mutations tied to cancer, such as the enzyme [[src Kinase]] and certain forms of the [[Engrailed (gene) | Engrailed]] [[Homeodomain]]. These proteins also have a great deal of experimental data for comparison, and serve as a great system for the understanding of folding and misfolding.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2009/12/release-of-new-protomol-core-b4-wus-.html | title = Release of new Protomol (Core B4) WUs | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2009-12-22 | accessdate = 2011-09-23}}{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=180 | title = Project 180 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} Additionally, the Pande lab is using Folding@home to understand the dynamics of a small [[Trefoil knot fold | knottin]] protein and how it can be used to bind to [[contrast agent]]s for [[Medical imaging | imaging scan]] or [[drug]]s.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=7600 | title = Project 7600 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} Finally, some forms of [[interleukin-2]], an important signaling protein for the immune system, have been used as [[immunotherapy]] for cancer. The Pande lab believes that Folding@home's simulations of its dynamics will lead to insights into how to design other [[therapeutic]]s.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=10113 | title = Project 10113 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} ===Parkinson's disease=== [[Parkinson's disease]] is a [[Neurodegeneration|degenerative]] disorder of the [[central nervous system]], characterized by shaking, rigidity, [[Bradykinesia|slowness of movement]], and [[dementia]]. The Pande lab has performed preliminary studies on the properties of [[alpha-synuclein]], a key [[intrinsically unstructured proteins|natively unfolded protein]]. Particular mutations of alpha-synuclein can aggregate to form toxic fibrils, and while the mechanism of this aggregation remains largely unknown, it can lead to the Parkinson's disease and other conditions.{{cite journal | author = Arima K, UÃ©da K, Sunohara N, Hirai S, Izumiyama Y, Tonozuka-Uehara H, Kawai M | title = Immunoelectron-microscopic demonstration of NACP/alpha-synuclein-epitopes on the filamentous component of Lewy bodies in Parkinson's disease and in dementia with Lewy bodies | journal = Brain Res. | volume = 808 | issue = 1 | pages = 93â100 | year = 1998 | month = October | pmid = 9795161 | doi = 10.1016/S0006-8993(98)00734-3 | url = | issn = }} The Pande lab is also testing how Folding@home's methods apply to this problem, and in 2005, Pande presented results from FAH at a [[National Parkinson Foundation]] conference. ===Osteogenesis imperfecta=== [[Osteogenesis imperfecta]] is a non-curable genetic bone disorder. Those with the disease are unable to successfully make functional connective bone tissue. This is lethal for many but can also induce a higher rate of [[miscarriages]]. The disease is caused by mutations in the Type-1 [[collagen]] protein, the most common form of collagen and found abundantly throughout the body. Although some of these mutations of collagen can lead to serious morphological disorders, more benign forms can cause brittle bones and other subtleties. Folding@home has performed simulations of collagen, and has produced a paper on Osteogenesis imperfecta outlining new molecular simulation techniques and revealing new insights into how collagen misfolds. The Pande lab believes these results will be useful for later computational studies of collagen.{{cite journal | author = Sanghyun Park, Randall J. Radmer, Teri E. Klein, and Vijay S. Pande | title = A New Set of Molecular Mechanics Parameters for Hydroxyproline and Its Use in Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Collagen-Like Peptides | journal = Journal of Computational Chemistry | year = 2005 | volume = 26 | issue = 15 | pages = 1612â1616 | doi = 10.1002/jcc.20301 | pmid = 16170799}} ===Viruses=== Folding@home is also performing simulations of certain [[virus]]es such as [[influenza]] and [[HIV]]. These viruses are widespread, have a history of causing global [[pandemic]]s, and are exceptionally difficult to treat. While the majority of treatments focus on preventing [[viral replication]], Folding@home's research concentrates on preventing the virus from entering [[cellular membrane]]s in the first place. [[Membrane fusion]] is a primary action that occurs during this [[viral entry]], and an understanding of this process has implications for [[antiviral drug]]s and national health. Unfortunately, membrane mechanisms are difficult to analyse experimentally. Molecular dynamics simulations run on Folding@home can simulate the [[protein-lipid interaction]]s involved during cellular viral infection, which have improved the Pande lab's understanding of the molecular dynamics behind this process.{{cite web | url = http://www.stanford.edu/~kasson/Membrane_Fusion.html | title = Membrane Fusion | author = Peter Kasson | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-12-02}} Research using Folding@home also continues on the dynamics of the enzyme [[RNase H]], a key component of HIV, in the hopes of designing drugs to deactivate it.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=66&t=19423&p=193871#p193871 | title = Project 10125 | author = Gregory Bowman (Pande Group Member) | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-12-02}} ===Drug design=== [[Drug design]] has two components; [[protein docking]] and [[free energy calculation]]. These are difficult and time-consuming to determine experimentally and traditional computational approaches must usually trade speed for accuracy.{{cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/3597738.stm | title = Home computers aid disease fight | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 2004-09-18 | accessdate = 2011-12-01}} Moreover, free energy calculation of molecular processes is a challenge in [[computational chemistry]], but is [[pharmaceutic]]ally useful.{{cite journal | author = Guha Jayachandran, M. R. Shirts, S. Park, and V. S. Pande | title = Parallelized-Over-Parts Computation of Absolute Binding Free Energy with Docking and Molecular Dynamics | journal = Journal of Chemical Physics | year = 2006 | volume = 125 | issue = 8 | pages = 084901 | doi = 10.1063/1.2221680 | pmid = 16965051 | bibcode = 2006JChPh.125h4901J}}{{cite journal | author = Hideaki Fujutani, Yoshiaki Tanida, Masakatsu Ito, Guha Jayachandran, Christopher D. Snow, Michael R. Shirts, Eric J. Sorin, and Vijay S. Pande | title = Direct calculation of the binding free energies of FKBP ligands using the Fujitsu BioServer massively parallel computer | journal = Journal of Chemical Physics | year = 2005 | volume = 123 | issue = 8 | pages = 084108 | doi = 10.1063/1.1999637 | pmid = 16164283 | bibcode = 2005JChPh.123h4108F}} In 2006 the Pande lab presented methods for FAH which parallelized these calculations, which increased significantly increased computational efficiency compared to previous techniques. These methods had implications in docking, molecular dynamics, and [[free energy perturbation]], and allowed Folding@home to perform drug design calculations that were otherwise infeasible. Scientists can utilize Folding@home to precisely demonstrate how potential drugs will bind to proteins, which is important because a [[ligand]] that strongly [[ligand binding | binds]] to a target protein is a promising drug candidate. In 2011 as part of a [[blind experiment]], Folding@home attempted to predict which of a set of [[ligand]]s would attach to a target protein and also estimate their associated [[binding energy | binding energies]].{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=66&t=18718#p187215 | title = New projects 3865-3867 in beta | author = Michael Shirts (Pande Group Member) | date = 2011-05-23 | accessdate = 2011-12-01}}{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=3855 | title = Project 3855 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-12-01}} As of 2011, Folding@home is searching for prime [[binding site | binding locations]] on protein surfaces by testing the interactions of different molecules with known binding sites.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=2450 | title = Project 2450 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} Additionally, studies are also underway on the dynamics of [[beta-lactamase]], a protein that plays important roles in [[drug resistance]]. Following the results from this study, the Pande lab may be able to design drugs to deactivate it.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=10115 | title = Project 10115 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-09-27}} As part of the drug design efforts, Folding@home also simulates the [[ribosome]], a large biological machine that synthesizes proteins from [[mRNA]]. It is targeted by approximately half of all known [[antibiotics]], which usually kill bacteria by preventing their ribosomes from making new and essential proteins. The full structure of the ribosome has only been recently determined, but the functions of many [[ribosomal protein]]s remain largely unknown.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=5765 | title = Project 5765 Description | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-12-02}} In 2007 the Pande lab received a [[grant]] to study and design new antibiotics. The size and complexity of the ribosome has prepared the Pande lab for more complex biomedical problems. ==Participation== [[Image:FAH-tflops.PNG| thumb | left | 260px | Folding@home computing power shown, by device type, in tera[[FLOPS]] as recorded semi-daily from November 2006 until September 2007. Note the large spike in total compute power after March 22, when the [[PlayStation 3]] client was released.]] Interest and participation in the project has grown steadily since its launch.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2007/10/fun-fact-fah-gr.html | title = Fun fact: FAH growth over time | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2007-10-21 | accessdate = 2011-10-21}}{{cite web | url = http://www.stanford.edu/group/pandegroup/images/ActiveCPUs2010.png | title = Active CPUs | format = Image | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | accessdate = 2011-08-30}} As of November 17, 2011, Folding@home has about 439,000 active [[CPU]]s, about 37,000 active [[GPU]]s, and about 21,000 active [[PlayStation 3|PS3s]], for a total of about 6.7 native [[petaflop|petaFLOPS]], (9.1 [[x86]] petaFLOPS) more computing power than the combined efforts of all distributed computing projects under BOINC.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/main.py?qtype=osstats | title = Client Statistics by OS | author = Pande lab | date = updated automatically | publisher = Stanford University | accessdate = 2011-09-28}}{{cite web | url = http://boincstats.com/stats/project_graph.php?pr=bo | title = BOINC Combined Credit Overview | accessdate = 2011-11-17}} A large majority of this performance comes from the GPU and PS3 clients. Folding@home achieves [[strong scaling]] across its user base; it gains a near-linear speedup for every additional processor.{{cite journal | author = Michael R. Shirts and Vijay S. Pande | title = Mathematical Foundations of Coupled Parallel Simulations | journal = Physical Review Letters | year = 2001 | volume = 86 | issue = 22 | pages = 4983â4987 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.86.4983 | pmid = 11384401 | bibcode = 2001PhRvL..86.4983S}} In 2007, [[Guinness World Records|Guinness]] recognized Folding@home as the most powerful distributed computing cluster in the world.{{cite web | url = http://www.engadget.com/2007/10/31/folding-home-recognized-by-guinness-world-records/ | title = Folding@Home recognized by Guinness World Records | author = Joshua Topolsky | date = 2007-10-31 | accessdate = 2007-11-05}} This large and powerful network allows FAH to do work not possible any other way, including through the use of supercomputers,{{cite journal | author = Caroline Hadley | title = Biologists think bigger | journal = EMBO reports | year = 2004 | volume = 12 | issue = 5 | pages = 236â238 | doi = 10.1038/sj.embor.7400108 | pmid = | url = http://www.nature.com/embor/journal/v5/n3/full/7400108.html}} which are typically expensive to operate and often shared. Folding@home gained popularity early in its history. In March 2002, [[Google]] co-founder [[Sergey Brin]] launched [[Google Compute]] as add-on for the [[Google Toolbar]].{{Cite news | url = http://news.cnet.com/2100-1001-867091.html | title = Google takes on supercomputing | date = March 22, 2002 | publisher = CNet News | first = Stephen | last = Shankland}} Although limited in functionality and scope, it increased Folding@home's participation from 10,000 up to about 30,000 active CPUs. The program ended in October 2005 in favor of the Pande lab's official clients, and is no longer available for the Toolbar.{{Cite news | url = http://hardforum.com/showpost.php?p=1028770683&postcount=4 | title = Google is after your CPU cycles | author = ChelseaOilman | date = 2005-12-30 | accessdate = 2011-09-06}}{{Cite news | url = http://toolbar.google.com/dc/offerdc.html/ | title = Your computer's idle time is too precious to waste | author = Google | year = 2007 | accessdate = 2011-09-06}} Folding@home also gained participants from [[Genome@home]], another distributed computing project from the Pande lab and a sister project to Folding@home. The goal of Genome@home was [[protein design]] and its applications, and the project was officially concluded in March 2004. Following its completion, users were asked to donate to Folding@home instead.{{Cite news | url = http://www.stanford.edu/group/pandegroup/genome/new.html | title = Genome@home Updates | date = 2002-03-04 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}}{{Cite news | url = http://genomeathome.stanford.edu/faq.html | title = Genome@home FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | accessdate = 2011-09-05}} ===PetaFLOPS milestones=== {| align="right" border="1" class="wikitable" style="margin-left:5px" |- !
