For instance, certain complex functions can be performed in one native FLOP on a GPU, but take multiple FLOPS on the x86 architecture.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-flops | title = Folding@home FLOP FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2009-04-04 | accessdate = 2011-08-28}} Despite using conservative conversions, for the GPU and PS3 clients x86 FLOPS are consistently much greater than the native FLOPS.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/FAQ-PS3.html | title = PS3 FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2009-02-05 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}} By reporting in both native and x86 FLOPS, Folding@home attempts to even out these hardware differences. ==Points== Distributed computing projects such as Folding@home are often driven by a sense of collegiate competition to compute the most for the project. Folding@home quantitatively assesses this through a point system.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-Points | title = Folding@home Points FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2011-02-16 | accessdate = 2011-08-31}}{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-PointsNew | title = Folding@home Points FAQ (New Benchmark Machine -- January 2010) | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2011-02-16 | accessdate = 2011-08-31}} Donors are granted point credit as a measure of their contribution, and these points can foster friendly competition between donors. Points are determined by the performance of each contributor's folding hardware relative to a reference machine, and one or more Work Units from a project are benchmarked on that machine before the project is released. As some simulations are exceptionally demanding on a system, or are of great scientific priority, donors who opt-in and reliably complete these Work Units are non-linearly rewarded additional bonus points.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=13038 | title = Upcoming Release of SMP2 Cores | author = Peter Kasson (Pande lab member) | date = 2010-01-24 | accessdate = 2011-08-31}} This generates a fair system of equal pay for equal work, and attempts to align credit with the value of the scientific results. Donors can also use a passkey to securely protect their contributions, as they not only allow for the receipt of bonus points, but they also separate a donor from any policy issues arising from another using that username.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-passkey | title = Folding@home Passkey FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2011-05-24 | accessdate = 2011-09-06}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=19712#p196346 | title = Re: Passkey when changing username | author = Tim "7im" Braun | date = 2011-09-29 | accessdate = 2011-10-02}} Users can register their contributions under a team, which register the combined score of all their members. A user can start their own team, or they can join an existing team.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/main.py?qtype=teampage&teamnum=0 | title = Default Team | accessdate = 2011-09-06}} They can be used for troubleshooting or recruitment purposes, but can also keep donors motivated.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=47&t=12499#p122465 | title = Re: New to F@H need startup info | author = MtM | date = 2009-12-17 | accessdate = 2011-09-30}} In some cases, a team may have their own community-driven sources of help such as a [[Internet forum|forum]].{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=11242&start=0#p109792 | title = Re: Why join a team? | date = 2009-08-28 | accessdate = 2011-09-08}}{{cite web | url = http://forums.extremeoverclocking.com/forumdisplay.php?f=45 | title = Official Extreme Overclocking Folding@Home Team Forum | publisher = Extreme Overclocking | accessdate = 2011-09-08}} In addition, rivalries between teams create friendly competition that benefits the folding community,{{cite web | url = http://www.maximumpc.com/article/news/help_maximum_pcs_folding_team_win_next_chimp_challenge | title = Help Maximum PC's Folding Team Win the Next Chimp Challenge! | author = Norman Chan | date = 2009-04-06 | accessdate = 2011-09-06}} and members can also have intra-team competitions for top spots.{{cite web | url = http://forums.overclockers.com.au/showthread.php?t=940743 | title = Team 24 Folding at Home - March Challenge | date = 2011-02-20 | accessdate = 2011-09-06}}{{cite web | url = http://imminst.org/announcing-foldinghome-prize | title = Announcing the F@H Prize | publisher = Immortality Institute | accessdate = 2011-09-06}} However, regardless of username or team affiliation, all contributions go to the same place and have the same scientific value. Rankings and other statistics for both individuals and teams are posted to the Folding@home website, with third party statistics sites also available.{{cite web | url = http://fahwiki.net/index.php/Third_Party_Contributions#Stats_Pages | title = Third Party Contributions - Stats Pages | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-08-07}} ==Software== Folding@home software on the user's end consists of three components: a client, work units, and cores. ===Client=== Folding@home is powered by volunteers who have installed a [[client (computing)|client]] [[computer program|program]] on their [[personal computer]]. The project differs from other distributed computing projects, such as those under BOINC, by offering a variety of clients such as those for [[multi-core processor]]s, [[graphics processing unit]]s, and [[PlayStation 3]]s, complementing the standard client designed for [[uniprocessor]] systems. While the former clients use significantly more system resources, they also have the capability of completing an overall simulation very quickly, (in a few weeks or months rather than years) which is of major scientific value.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-SMP | title = Folding@home SMP FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2010-12-11 | accessdate = 2011-08-31}} Folding@home is the first project to fully utilize GPUs, PS3s, or multi-core processors for distributed computing.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/05/gpu-news-gpu1-g.html | title = GPU news (about GPU1, GPU2, & NVIDIA support) | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-05-23 | accessdate = 2011-09-08}}{{cite journal | author = Travis Desell1, Anthony Waters, Malik Magdon-Ismail, Boleslaw K. Szymanski, Carlos A. Varela, Matthew Newby, Heidi Newberg, Andreas Przystawik, and David Anderson | title = Accelerating the MilkyWay@Home volunteer computing project with GPUs | journal = 8th International Conference on Parallel Processing and Applied Mathematics (PPAM 2009) | year = 2009 | volume = | issue = | pages = | doi = 10.1.1.158.7614 | pmid = | url = http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.158.7614&rep=rep1&type=pdf}}{{cite journal | author = M. J. Harvey, G. Giupponi, Vill`a-Freixa, and G. De Fabritiis | title = PS3GRID.NET: Building a distributed supercomputer using the PlayStation 3 | journal = Distributed & Grid Computing - Science Made Transparent for EVeryone. Principles, Applications and Supporting Communities | year = 2007 | volume = | issue = | pages = | doi = | pmid = | url = http://www.gpugrid.net/pub/ps3grid_chapter.pdf}} As its software is custom-tailored to each [[hardware architecture]], Folding@home gains the ability to run many different types of calculations, allowing the Pande lab to address questions previously considered impossible to tackle computationally, and make even greater impacts on knowledge of protein misfolding and its related diseases. Each client is the software with which the user interacts, and manages the other software components behind the scenes.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/WinUNIGuide | title = Windows Uniprocessor Client Installation Guide | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | date = 2011-02-10 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}} Through the client, the user may pause the folding process, open an event log, check the work progress, or view personal statistics. These clients run continuously in the [[background (computer software)|background]], using otherwise unused processing power. These clients are designed to run FAH's calculations at an extremely low priority, and will back off to allow other computer programs to have more processing power.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=1164#p9750 | title = Answers to: Reasons for not using F@H | author = John Naylor | date = 2008-02-09 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=19555#p195220 | title = Re: F@h Advertisement Techniques | author = Bruce Borden (bruce) | date = 2011-09-11 | accessdate = 2011-10-18}} Although modern computer chips are designed to be able to operate continuously without degrading,{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=1164&start=75#p58696 | title = Answers to: Reasons for not using F@H | author = Tim "7im" Braun | date = 2008-09-28 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}} if users wish to reduce power consumption or heat production, the maximum percentage of CPU power used can be adjusted if desired. If interrupted by a computer shutdown or other means, the client will resume work at almost the same point at startup.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=1164&start=75#p43364 | title = Re: Answers to: Reasons for not using F@H | author = Bruce Borden (bruce) | date = 2008-07-28 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}} For users with machines with multiple processor units, multiple clients may be installed on one machine, and users may be credited by clients on multiple machines.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-main | title = Folding@home Main FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2011-08-18 | accessdate = 2011-10-23}} For security and scientific integrity reasons, the Pande lab does not publicly release the [[source code]] of the clients.{{cite web | url =http://folding.typepad.com/news/2009/08/importance-of-software-and-data-integrity.html | title = Importance of software and data integrity | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2009-08-20 | accessdate = 2011-10-19}} Significant work goes into minimizing security issues in all of Folding@home's software.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=19163#p191513 | title = Re: Advice for a new user | author = Bruce Borden (bruce) | date = 2011-07-18 | accessdate = 2011-09-11}} For example, clients can be downloaded only from the official Folding@home website or its commercial partners. It will upload and download data only from Stanford's Folding@home data servers, (over [[Computer port (software)|port]] 8080, with 80 as an alternative){{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-Uninstall | title = Uninstalling Folding@home FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | date = 2009-11-19 | accessdate = 2011-09-21}} and will only interact with FAH computer files. Moreover, it does not normally need computer [[administrative privileges]], so from a security standpoint it behaves similar to but is even more secure than a [[web browser]]. Folding@home's first client was a [[screensaver]], which would run Folding@home while the computer was not otherwise in use.{{cite journal | author = M. R. Shirts and V. S. Pande. | title = Screen Savers of the World, Unite! | journal = Science | year = 2000 | volume = 290 | issue = 5498 | pages = 1903â1904 | doi = 10.1126/science.290.5498.1903 | pmid = 17742054}} Later, the Pande lab tested clients on the open source [[BOINC]] framework; however, this approach became unworkable and was abandoned in June 2006.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-highperformance | title = High Performance FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2010-05-13 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}} Both BOINC and Folding@home clients fell short, for neither client type had enough ability to be compatible with the other. BOINC lacked many features that FAH needed, and FAH lacked features that BOINC needed.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=1164&start=135#p137893 | title = Re: Answers to: Reasons for not using F@H | author = Tim "7im" Braun | date = 2010-04-02 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}} ====Graphics processing units==== [[GPU]]s are computer chips used to accelerate 3D graphics, which are most commonly found in video games. GPUs have the capability to significantly out-perform [[CPU]]s in terms of Floating Point OPerations, ([[FLOP]]s) at the cost of lower generality.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2007/09/how-fah-works-f.html | title = How FAH works: Folding on streaming processors (GPU's and PS3) | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2007-09-24 | accessdate = 2011-10-29}} For this reason, high-performance computing is increasingly utilizing the GPU specialized hardware. In the first large-scale test of GPU scientific reliability, the Pande lab found that although GPUs lack built-in memory [[error detection and correction]], reliable scientific computation can be performed on consumer-grade hardware, as long as sufficient measures are taken (such as Folding@home's built-in error detection) to ensure data integrity.{{cite journal | author = I. Haque and V. S. Pande | title = Hard Data on Soft Errors: A Large-Scale Assessment of Real-World Error Rates in GPGPU | journal = 2010 10th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Cluster, Cloud and Grid Computing (CCGrid) | year = 2010 | volume = | issue = | pages = 691â696 | doi = 10.1109/CCGRID.2010.84 | pmc = | pmid = }} Despite their potential benefits, scientific computing on GPUs has previously remained inefficient and difficult. The Pande lab has been able to write [[OpenMM]], an [[open source]] molecular dynamics [[Library (computing) | library]] optimized to take full advantage of the GPU architecture and gain large speed increases over conventional single-CPU implementations.{{cite journal | author = M. S. Friedrichs, P. Eastman, V. Vaidyanathan, M. Houston, S. LeGrand, A. L. Beberg, D. L. Ensign, C. M. Bruns, V. S. Pande | title = Accelerating Molecular Dynamic Simulation on Graphics Processing Units | journal = Journal of Computational Chemistry | year = 2009 | volume = 30 | issue = 6 | pages = 864â72 | doi = 10.1002/jcc.21209 | pmid = 19191337 | pmc = 2724265}} As an [[abstraction layer]], OpenMM allows molecular dynamics simulations to be efficiently run across a variety of computer architectures and platforms, something previously problematic in scientific software development.{{cite journal | author = P. Eastman and V. S. Pande | title = OpenMM: A Hardware Abstraction Layer for Molecular Simulations | journal = Computing in Science & Engineering | year = 2010 | volume = 12 | issue = 4 | pages = 34â39 | doi = 10.1109/MCSE.2010.27 | pmc = | pmid = }} GPUs remain the most powerful platform available in terms of [[FLOPS]]; as of September 23, 2011, GPU clients account for 71% of the entire project's FLOP throughput. The first generation of Folding@home's [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] GPU client (GPU1) was released to the public on October 2, 2006, and delivered a 20-30X speedup for certain calculations over its CPU-based [[Gromacs]] counterparts.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-ATI | title = ATI FAQ | format = FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | date = 2011-03-18 | accessdate = 2011-08-31}} It was the first time GPUs had been used for either distributed computing or major molecular dynamics calculations. The Pande lab learned much about the development of [[GPGPU]] software, but citing a need to improve scientific accuracies over [[DirectX]],{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/05/gpu1-to-gpu2-transition-why-does-gpu1-need-to-end.html | title = More info about the GPU1 to GPU2 transition | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-05-27 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}} it was succeeded by GPU2, the second generation successor of the client on April 10, 2008.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/04/gpu2-open-beta.html | title = GPU2 open beta | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-04-10 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}} Several months later, GPU1 was officially retired on June 6.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/06/gpu1-has-been-retired-gpu2-for-nvidia-release-nearing.html | title = GPU1 has been retired, GPU2 for NVIDIA release nearing | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-06-06 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}} Compared to GPU1, GPU2 was more scientifically reliable and productive, ran on [[ATI]] and [[CUDA]]-enabled [[Nvidia]] GPUs, and supported more advanced algorithms, larger proteins, and real-time visualization of the protein simulation.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/04/updates-to-the.html | title = Updates to the Download page/GPU2 goes live | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-04-15 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}}{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/04/gpu2-open-bet-1.html | title = GPU2 open beta going well | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-04-11 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}} Following this, the third generation of Folding@home's GPU client (GPU3) was released on May 25, 2010. While [[backwards compatible]] to GPU2, GPU3 is more stable and efficient, has additional scientific capabilities,{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/01/code-developmen.html | title = Code Development Updates | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-01-25 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}}{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2010/04/prepping-for-the-gpu3-rolling-new-client-and-nvidia-fah-gpu-clients-will-need-cuda-22-or-later.html | title = Prepping for the GPU3 rolling: new client and NVIDIA FAH GPU clients will (in the future) need CUDA 2.2 or later | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2010-04-24 | accessdate = 2011-09-08}} and uses the Pande lab's [[OpenMM]] library on top of an [[OpenCL]] framework.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2010/05/open-beta-release-of-the-gpu3-clientcore.html | title = Folding@home: Open beta release of the GPU3 client/core | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2010-05-25 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}} Although it does not natively support the [[Linux]] operating system, it can be run under [[WINE (software) | WINE]] for donors with Nvidia graphics cards.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=67&t=19795&start=45#p197198 | title = Re: FAHClient V7.1.38 released (4th Open-Beta) | author = Joseph Coffland | date = 2011-10-13 | accessdate = 2011-10-15}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=54&t=6793 | title = NVIDIA GPU3 Linux/Wine Headless Install Guide | date = 2008-11-08 | accessdate = 2011-09-05}} ====PlayStation 3==== {{further | [[Life with PlayStation]]}} [[Image:LifeWithPlayStation Folding.jpg|right | thumb | 280px | The PlayStation 3's ''Life With PlayStation'' client displays a 3D animation of the protein being folded]] Folding@home can also take advantage of the computing power of [[PlayStation 3]]s, to achieve performance previously only possible on supercomputers. Unlike Microsoft's [[Xbox]], the PS3 is well suited for Folding@home simulations. At the time of its inception and for certain calculations, its main [[stream processing|streaming processor]] [[Cell processor]] delivered a 20x speed increase over PCs, allowing the Pande lab to address problems previously considered impossible to tackle computationally.{{cite web | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2006/TECH/fun.games/09/18/playstation.folding/ | title = PlayStation's serious side: Fighting disease | author = David E. Williams | publisher = [[CNN]] | date = 2006-10-20 | accessdate = 2011-10-16}} This high speed and efficiency introduced other opportunities for [[Amdahl's law|worthwhile]] optimizations, and radically changed the tradeoff between computational efficiency and overall accuracy, allowing for the utilization of more complex molecular models at little extra computational cost.{{cite journal | author = Edgar Luttmann, Daniel L. Ensign, Vishal Vaidyanathan, Mike Houston, Noam Rimon, Jeppe Ãland, Guha Jayachandran, Mark Friedrichs, Vijay S. Pande | title = Accelerating Molecular Dynamic Simulation on the Cell processor and PlayStation 3 | journal = Journal of Computational Chemistry | year = 2008 | volume = 30 | issue = 2 | pages = 268â274 | doi = 10.1002/jcc.21054 | pmid = 18615421}} These capabilities allow for greater insights into disease research. The PS3 client was originally a standalone application, but since September 18, 2008 is a channel of [[Life with PlayStation]], developed in a collaborative effort between [[Sony]] and the Pande lab. It takes the middle path between a CPU's flexibility and a GPU's speed, performing a limited set of calculations rapidly while still retaining adaptable. However, unlike CPUs and GPUs, donors cannot perform other activities on their PS3 while running Folding@home. Instead, the Pande lab has specifically designed its Work Units to take approximately eight hours so that they can be completed overnight. The PS3's uniform console environment makes [[technical support|support]] easier, as well as making Folding@home [[user friendly]]. The PS3 also has the ability to stream data quickly to its GPU, allowing for real-time atomic detail visualizations of the protein dynamics. ====Multi-core processing client==== The [[symmetric multiprocessing|Symmetric MultiProcessing]] (SMP) client fulfills two purposes: it takes advantage of the high-performance capabilities of recent [[multi-core (computing)|multiprocessor]] systems, and it helps develop a simulation architecture that will become one of the dominant FAH computing paradigms as multi-core chips become an industry standard over the next several years. The SMP client is capable of delivering over a 4x calculation speedup over the standard uniprocessor clients. Folding@home's SMP core handles multi-core CPUs very different from other distributed computing projects, including those under [[BOINC]].{{cite web | url = http://boincfaq.mundayweb.com/index.php?language=1&view=115&sessionID=f68532da1ffd360def2213188757c695 | title = Can I have multiple CPUs work on the same task (workunit)? | author = Ozzfan | publisher = BOINC | date = 2007-10-01 | accessdate = 2011-10-09}} Instead of simply doing multiple Work Units simultaneously, single WUs are completed much faster across the multiple CPU cores.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/06/what-does-the-smp-core-do.html | title = What does the SMP core do? | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-06-15 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}} This cuts down on the traditional difficulties of scaling a large simulation to many processors. As such, this approach is very scientifically valuable. Some of the Pande lab publications would not have been possible without the SMP client. On November 13, 2006, first generation SMP Folding@home clients for [[x86]] [[Microsoft Windows]], [[x86-64]] [[Linux]], and x86 [[Mac OS X]] were released. These clients used [[Message Passing Interface]] (MPI) protocols on the [[localhost]], as at the time the Gromacs cores were not designed to be used with multiple [[Thread (computer science)|thread]]s. This made Folding@home the first to use MPI for distributed computing software, as it had previously been reserved only for supercomputers.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2008/03/new-windows-cli.html | title = New Windows client/core development (SMP and classic clients) | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-03-08 | accessdate = 2011-09-30}} The MPI-based clients worked well in [[Unix]]-based operating systems such as [[Linux]] and Mac's [[OS-X]], but was particularly troublesome in Windows. Despite these difficulties, SMP1 generated significant results that would have been impossible otherwise and which represented a landmark in the simulation of protein folding. The second generation of the SMP client was released as an open beta on January 24, 2010, and subsequently replaced SMP1.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=13038#p127406 | title = upcoming release of SMP2 cores | author = Peter Kasson (Pande lab member) | date = 2010-01-24 | accessdate = 2011-09-30}} The SMP2 client exchanges the complex MPI for [[Thread (computer science)|thread]]s, which removes much of the overhead of keeping the cores synchronized.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2009/06/how-does-fah-code-development-and-sysadmin-get-done.html | title = How does FAH code development and sysadmin get done? | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2009-06-17 | accessdate = 2011-10-14}} The SMP2 client also supports a bonus points system, which non-linearly rewards additional points to donors for quick WU returns and for contributing to next-generation capabilities. Donors who run the SMP2 client receive these extra points if they use a passkey and maintained an 80% successful return of Work Units. SMP2 also supports extra-large Work Units for users with powerful eight-core CPUs or better. While these WUs consume even more [[RAM]] and have more network usage than regular SMP WUs, users who run these are rewarded with a 20% increase over SMP2's bonus point system.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2011/07/change-in-the-points-system-for-bigadv-work-units.html | title = Change in the points system for bigadv work units | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2011-07-02 | accessdate = 2011-10-09}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?t=10697 | title = new release: extra-large work units | author = Peter Kasson (Pande lab member) | date = 2009-07-15 | accessdate = 2011-10-09}} These powerful computers allow for simulations to be performed on Folding@home that had previously required the use of supercomputing [[Computer cluster#Compute clusters|clusters]]. There is a great scientific need to run these simulations out to long timescales as quickly as possible, so the additional bonus points also serves as an incentive for rapid completions of Work Units. This allows the Pande lab to perform studies of larger molecular systems that would not have been possible anywhere else on Folding@home. ====V7==== [[Image:F@h v7 novice shot.png|thumb | 400px | A sample image of the v7 client in Novice mode running under [[Windows 7]]. In addition to a variety of controls and user details, v7 also presents Work Unit information, such as its state, calculation progress, ETA, credit points, and identification numbers.]] The v7 client is the seventh and latest generation of the Folding@home software, currently under development, but available for open beta testing. V7 is a complete rewrite and unification of the previous clients for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X]] and [[Linux]] operating systems.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2011/03/client-version-7-now-in-open-beta.html | title = Client version 7 now in open beta | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2011-03-29 | accessdate = 2011-08-14}}{{cite web | url = https://fah-web.stanford.edu/projects/FAHClient/wiki/ClientFAQ | title = Client FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-08-14}} Following its predecessors, v7 runs Folding@home in the background at very low priority, which allows other applications to use CPU resources as they need. The v7 client is designed to make the installation, start-up, and operation user-friendly for novices, as well as offer greater scientific flexibility than previous clients.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2011/03/core-16-for-ati-released-also-note-on-nvidia-gpu-support-for-older-boards.html | title = Core 16 for ATI released; also note on NVIDIA GPU support for older boards | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2011-03-31 | accessdate = 2011-09-07}} It is the Pande lab's goal to make v7 the recommended client by January 2012 at the latest,{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=67&t=19648#p195686 | title = FAHClient V7.1.33 released (3rd Open-Beta) | author = Joseph Coffland | date = 2011-09-19 | accessdate = 2011-09-19 }} and versions of v7 will be frequently released until then. V7 consists of several elements. The user interacts with v7's [[GUI]], known as FAHControl. It has Novice, Advanced, and Expert user interface modes, and has the ability to monitor, configure, and control many remote folding clients from a single computer. FAHControl can monitor and direct FAHClient, which runs behind the scenes and in turn manages each FAHSlot (or "slot"). These slots act as replacements for the previously distinct FAH clients, as they may be of Uniprocessor, SMP, or GPU type. Each slot also contains a core and data associated with it, and can download, process, and upload Work Units independently.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/WinGuide | title = Windows (FAH V7) Install Guide | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | date = 2011-09-23 | accessdate = 2011-10-09}} The FAHViewer function, modeled after the PS3 viewer, displays a real-time 3D rendering, if available, of the protein currently being processed. ===Work Units=== The Work Unit (WU) is the protein data that the client is being asked to process. Each WU is identified for its respective protein Project, Run (conformation), Clone (atomic trajectory), and Generation (time steps in the trajectory/simulation).{{cite web | url = http://fahwiki.net/index.php/Runs,_Clones_and_Gens | title = Runs, Clones, and Generations | author = Dan Ensign | accessdate = 2011-08-10}} The client connects to Folding@home [[Server (computing)|server]]s to retrieve a Work Unit, processes it, and returns it upon completion.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2007/09/how-fah-works-m.html | title = How FAH works: Markov State Models | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2007-09-22 | accessdate = 2011-10-14}} During transfer, all Work Units are validated through the use of 2048-bit [[digital signature]]s. These WUs have associated deadlines and credit (point) value. If this deadline is exceeded, the user may not get credit and the unit will be reissued to someone else. As protein folding is serial in nature and each WU is generated from its predecessor, this allows the overall simulation process to proceed normally if a WU is not returned after a certain period of time. Due to these deadlines, the minimum system requirements for Folding@home is a Pentium 3 450 MHz CPU with [[SSE]] or newer. However, Work Units for high performance clients have a much shorter deadline than those for the uniprocessor client, as a major part of the scientific benefit is dependent on rapidly completing simulations. Before public release, Work Units go through several [[Quality Assurance]] steps to keep problematic WUs from becoming fully available.{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2011/04/more-transparency-in-testing.html | title = More transparency in testing | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2011-04-05 | accessdate = 2011-10-14}} But unlike particular [[BOINC]] projects such as [[SETI@home]], Folding@home's Work Units are normally processed only once, except in the rare event that errors occur during processing of a WU. If this occurs for three different donors,{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=59&t=19315#p192836 | title = Re: Gromacs Cannot Continue Further | author = Bruce Borden (bruce) | date = 2011-08-07 | accessdate = 2011-08-07}} it is automatically pulled from distribution.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=19325&p=192927&hilit=8am#p192927 | title = Re: Project: 6053 (Run 1, Clone 194, Gen 357) | author = Bruce Borden (bruce) | date = 2011-08-09 | accessdate = 2011-08-09}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=19725#p196444 | title = Re: Project 6803: (Run 4, Clone 66, Gen 255) | author = PantherX | date = 2011-10-01 | accessdate = 2011-10-09}} Topics in the Folding@home forum can be used to differentiate between problematic hardware and an actual bad Work Unit.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=16526 | title = Troubleshooting Bad WUs | author = PantherX | date = 2010-10-31 | accessdate = 2011-08-07}} Work Units are very much tied to the Pande lab's simulation [[Hidden Markov model | Markov state models]], which allow for extensive [[Parallel computing | parallelization]] of very long simulation processes which otherwise seem intrinsically serial.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=10513 | title = Folding@home project descriptions - Project 10513 | author = Pande lab | accessdate = 2011-08-15}} During the folding process, proteins spend much of their time "waiting" in various states, before quickly transitioning to the next configuration. This allows for the unique possibility to simulate only a small fraction of the overall folding timescale, leading to significant speedups. The Pande lab achieves this by first dividing the protein's possible dynamics into a series of related conformation states, and creates WUs to calculate the rates of transition between these states. When the completed WUs are gathered, the Pande lab then runs sophisticated Bayesian [[Machine Learning]] algorithms which calculate which states are reasonable and the rates between them. This also [[Ensemble average | averages]] the molecular simulation [[Statistical ensemble | ensembles]], which is important so that direct, meaningful comparison between ''in silico'' simulations and ''in vitro'' experiments can be made.{{cite journal | author = Bojan Zagrovic, Christopher D. Snow, Michael R. Shirts, and Vijay S. Pande. | title = Simulation of Folding of a Small Alpha-helical Protein in Atomistic Detail using Worldwide distributed Computing | journal = Journal of Molecular Biology | year = 2002 | volume = 323 | issue = 5 | pages = 927â937 | doi = 10.1016/S0022-2836(02)00997-X | pmid = 12417204}}{{cite journal | author = Christopher D. Snow, Houbi Ngyen, Vijay S. Pande, and Martin Gruebele | title = Absolute comparison of simulated and experimental protein-folding dynamics | journal = Nature | year = 2002 | volume = 420 | issue = 6911 | pages = 102â106 | doi = 10.1038/nature01160 | pmid = 12422224}} This system is successful even at the millisecond timescale, compares well to traditional methods and experimental results, and allows for previously intractable problems to be within reach. ===Cores=== {{Main | Folding@home cores}} Specialized scientific computer programs, referred to as "cores," perform the calculations on the Work Unit behind the scenes.{{cite web | url = http://fahwiki.net/index.php/Cores | title = Cores - FaHWiki | format = FAQ | accessdate = 2007-11-06}} Folding@home's cores modified and [[Program optimization | optimized]] versions of [[molecular dynamics]] programs, including [[GROMACS]], [[AMBER]], [[TINKER]], [[CPMD]], SHARPEN, ProtoMol, [[BrookGPU]] and [[Desmond (software)|Desmond]].{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/QMD.html | title = Folding@home with QMD core FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2005-10-16 | accessdate = 2006-12-03}} Some of these cores perform explicit atom-by-atom [[molecular dynamics]] calculations,{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2007/09/how-fah-works-1.html | title = How FAH works: Molecular dynamics | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2007-09-26 | accessdate = 2011-10-14}} while others perform [[implicit solvation]] methods, which treat atoms as a mathematical continuum.{{cite journal | author = Roux B, Simonson T | title = Implicit solvent models | journal = Biophys. Chem. | volume = 78 | issue = 1â2 | pages = 1â20 | year = 1999 | month = April | pmid = 17030302 | doi = 10.1016/S0301-4622(98)00226-9 | issn = 0301-4622}} These cores are [[open-source software]] or are under similar licenses,{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-OpenSource | title = Folding@home Open Source FAQ | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | date = 2010-02-03 | accessdate = 2011-09-11}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=17&t=19545&p=194838#p194838 | title = Re: Utilizing this resource | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2011-09-06 | accessdate = 2011-09-11}} and are verified during download by 2048-bit digital signatures.{{cite web | url = http://folding.stanford.edu/English/FAQ-Policies | title = Folding@home Rules and Policies | author = Pande lab | publisher = [[Stanford University]] | format = FAQ | accessdate = 2011-09-11}} While the same core can be used by various versions of the client, separating the core from the client enables the scientific methods to be updated automatically as needed without a client update. ==Comparison to other molecular systems== [[Rosetta@home]] is a distributed computing project aimed at [[protein structure prediction]] and is one of the most successful approaches to this problem.{{cite journal | author = Gregory R. Bowman and Vijay S. Pande | title = Simulated tempering yields insight into the low-resolution Rosetta scoring function | journal = Proteins: Structure, Function, and Bioinformatics | year = 2009 | volume = 74 | issue = 3 | pages = 777â88 | doi = 10.1002/prot.22210 | pmc = | pmid = 18767152}} Folding@home and Rosetta@home address very different molecular questions.{{cite web | url = http://web.archive.org/web/20070927193033/http://forum.folding-community.org/viewtopic.php?p=125338 | title = Rosetta and Folding | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2006-03-05 | accessdate = 2011-11-09}} Although Rosetta@home does not provide information into how proteins fold, it does predict the protein's most likely final structure, which in some cases is used as a basis for Folding@home's projects.{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?p=188496#p188496 | title = Re: Course grained Protein folding in under 10 minutes | author = TJ Lane (Pande lab member) | date = 2011-06-09 | accessdate = 2011-10-15}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=17&t=19671#p195977 | title = Re: New Invention Unravels Mystery of Protein Folding | author = Bruce Borden (bruce) | date = 2011-09-24 | accessdate = 2011-10-29}} Rosetta's predictions can help FAH simulate the folding of larger proteins more efficiently. Folding@home can also verify Rosetta@home's results and find additional atomistic details of the protein's kinetics and folding pathway, which is intrinsically much more difficult. Folding@home's accurate simulations have also suggesting important novel implications into the fields of protein folding, structure prediction, and certain folding experiments,{{cite journal | author = Bojan Zagrovic, Christopher D. Snow, Siraj Khaliq, Michael R. Shirts, and Vijay S. Pande | title = Native-like Mean Structure in the Unfolded Ensemble of Small Proteins | journal = Journal of Molecular Biology | year = 2002 | volume = 323 | issue = 1 | pages = 153â164 | doi = 10.1016/S0022-2836(02)00888-4 | pmid = 12368107}} and have shown that Rosetta's structure prediction may benefit from thermodynamic sampling aspects of protein folding mechanisms.{{cite journal | author = G. R. Bowman and V. S. Pande | title = The Roles of Entropy and Kinetics in Structure Prediction | journal = PLoS ONE | year = 2009 | volume = 4 | issue = 6 | pages = e5840 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0005840 | pmid = 19513117 | pmc = 2688754 | bibcode = 2009PLoSO...4.5840B | editor1-last = Hofmann | editor1-first = Andreas}}{{cite web | url = http://foldingforum.org/viewtopic.php?f=15&t=2322&p=20638#p20642 | title = Re: collaborating with competition | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2008-04-26 | accessdate = 2011-11-09}} Folding@home also compares well to [[Anton (computer) | Anton]], a powerful supercomputer which uses specialized hardware to produce a small number of ultra-long molecular trajectories. It is unique in this ability, and like Folding@home, has also improved particular long-held theories of protein folding. Its longer simulations, while computationally expensive, contain more [[phase space]] than any one of Folding@home's many shorter trajectories, which allows Anton to perform a thorough exploration of the required space.{{cite journal | author = Thomas J. Lane, Gregory R. Bowman, Kyle A Beauchamp, Vincent Alvin Voelz, and Vijay S. Pande | title = Markov State Model Reveals Folding and Functional Dynamics in Ultra-Long MD Trajectories | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | year = 2011 | volume = | issue = | pages = | doi = 10.1021/ja207470h | pmid = }} As of October 2011, Anton and FAH are the two most powerful molecular dynamics systems,{{cite web | url = http://folding.typepad.com/news/2011/10/comparison-between-fah-and-antons-approaches.html | title = Comparison between FAH and Anton's approaches | author = Vijay Pande | date = 2011-10-13 | accessdate = 2011-10-13}} and Anton has also run simulations out to the millisecond range.{{cite web | url = http://www.nature.com/news/2010/101014/full/news.2010.541.html | title = Supercomputer sets protein-folding record | author = Heidi Ledford | publisher = Nature News | date = 2010-10-14 | accessdate = 2011-10-15 | doi = 10.1038/news.2010.541}}{{cite journal | author = David E. Shaw, Paul Maragakis, Kresten Lindorff-Larsen, Stefano Piana, Ron O. Dror, Michael P. Eastwood, Joseph A. Bank, John M. Jumper, John K. Salmon, Yibing Shan, and Willy Wriggers | title = Atomic-Level Characterization of the Structural Dynamics of Proteins | journal = Science | year = 2010 | volume = 330 | issue = 6002 | pages = 341â346 | doi = 10.1126/science.1187409 | pmid = 20947758 | pmc = | bibcode = }} In 2011, the Pande lab built a Markov state model from one of Anton's simulations. It demonstrated that there was little difference between MSMs built from Anton's fewer long trajectories and one assembled from Folding@home's many shorter trajectories. Their analysis also showed that Folding@home's Markov state models significantly improve the analysis of these longer simulations, such as revealing additional relevant folding pathways and information into how the protein carries out its biological function. Folding@home is running further analysis on one of Anton's simulations to better determine how its approaches compare to Anton's methods.{{cite web | url = http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/fahproject.overusingIPswillbebanned?p=7610 | title = Project 7610 Description | author = Pande lab | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-10-14}} It is probable that a combination of Anton's and FAH's simulation methods would be very beneficial, and Pande looks forward to see how Anton and FAH can be used together. ==See also== * [[Storage@home]] * [[List of distributed computing projects]] * [[List of software for molecular mechanics modeling | Software for molecular modeling]] * [[Molecular modeling on GPU]]s * [[Rosetta@home]] * [[Blue Gene]] * [[Molecular dynamics]] * [[Computational biology]] ==External links== *[http://folding.stanford.edu/ Folding@home homepage] *[http://folding.typepad.com Folding@home official blog] *[http://foldingforum.org/ Folding@home forum] *[http://folding.stanford.edu/Stats Folding@home statistics] *[http://folding.stanford.edu/Papers List of publications from Folding@home's results] *[http://folding.typepad.com/news/2011/08/new-futures-in-biotech-episode-about-foldinghome.html "Futures In Biotech" episode (for newcomers)] *[http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/1070617 2009 Interview with Vijay Pande about Folding@home Project] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gFcp2Xpd29I&feature=feedwll Video of record-breaking 1.5ms protein fold] *[https://simtk.org/home/openmm Pande lab's OpenMM molecular dynamics library] *[http://icrontic.com/files/team93/videos/foldflash2.html Simple multimedia presentation about Folding@home] *[http://fahwiki.net/index.php/Main_Page Folding@home Wiki] *[http://fah-web.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/main.py?qtype=teampage&teamnum=42223 Wikipedia Team] ==Notes== [[#Note 1 back | Note 1:]] It should be noted that accurate measurement of the speed of a supercomputer does not necessarily equate to scientific productivity.
